ticket.title: Impossible to overwrite the default scope ordering in the named scope using relation syntax
ticket.original-body: Assuming we have @@@ ruby class DeveloperOrderedBySalary < ActiveRecord::Base self.table_name = 'developers' default_scope :order => 'salary DESC' scope :by_name, :order => 'name DESC' end @@@ Calling DeveloperOrderedBySalary.by_name will overwrite the default scope order (there is a test for this: test_named_scope_overwrites_default). But if we use the relation syntax @@@ ruby class DeveloperOrderedBySalary < ActiveRecord::Base self.table_name = 'developers' default_scope order('salary DESC') scope :by_name, order('name DESC') end @@@ DeveloperOrderedBySalary.by_name will not overwrite the ordering, but will concatenate it. I guess this is expected behavior according to https://rails.lighthouseapp.com/projects/8994-ruby-on-rails/tickets/4972-order-method-should-concatenate-and-reorder-should-overwrite But then I expect reorder to work in the named scope: @@@ ruby scope :by_name, reorder('name DESC') @@@ but this fails with undefined method `reorder' exception. This is because reorder is not delegated in ActiveRecord::Base like 'order' and other relation methods.
ticket.latest-body: Assuming we have @@@ ruby class DeveloperOrderedBySalary < ActiveRecord::Base self.table_name = 'developers' default_scope :order => 'salary DESC' scope :by_name, :order => 'name DESC' end @@@ Calling DeveloperOrderedBySalary.by_name will overwrite the default scope order (there is a test for this: test_named_scope_overwrites_default). But if we use the relation syntax @@@ ruby class DeveloperOrderedBySalary < ActiveRecord::Base self.table_name = 'developers' default_scope order('salary DESC') scope :by_name, order('name DESC') end @@@ DeveloperOrderedBySalary.by_name will not overwrite the ordering, but will concatenate it. I guess this is expected behavior according to https://rails.lighthouseapp.com/projects/8994-ruby-on-rails/tickets/4972-order-method-should-concatenate-and-reorder-should-overwrite But then I expect reorder to work in the named scope: @@@ ruby scope :by_name, reorder('name DESC') @@@ but this fails with undefined method `reorder' exception. This is because reorder is not delegated in ActiveRecord::Base like 'order' and other relation methods.
ticket.original-body-html:
Assuming we have

  class DeveloperOrderedBySalary < ActiveRecord::Base
    self.table_name = 'developers'
    default_scope :order => 'salary DESC'
    scope :by_name, :order => 'name DESC'
  end

Calling DeveloperOrderedBySalary.by_name will overwrite the default scope order (there is a test for this: test_named_scope_overwrites_default).

But if we use the relation syntax

  class DeveloperOrderedBySalary < ActiveRecord::Base
    self.table_name = 'developers'
    default_scope order('salary DESC')
    scope :by_name, order('name DESC')
  end

DeveloperOrderedBySalary.by_name will not overwrite the ordering, but will concatenate it. I guess this is expected behavior according to https://rails.lighthouseapp.com/projects/8994-ruby-on-rails/tickets...

But then I expect reorder to work in the named scope:

    scope :by_name, reorder('name DESC')

but this fails with undefined method reorder'</code> exception. This is because reorder is not delegated in ActiveRecord::Base like 'order' and other relation methods.

But if we use the relation syntax @@@ ruby class DeveloperOrderedBySalary < ActiveRecord::Base self.table_name = 'developers' default_scope order('salary DESC') scope :by_name, order('name DESC') end @@@ DeveloperOrderedBySalary.by_name will not overwrite the ordering, but will concatenate it. I guess this is expected behavior according to https://rails.lighthouseapp.com/projects/8994-ruby-on-rails/tickets/4972-order-method-should-concatenate-and-reorder-should-overwrite But then I expect reorder to work in the named scope: @@@ ruby scope :by_name, reorder('name DESC') @@@ but this fails with undefined method `reorder' exception. This is because reorder is not delegated in ActiveRecord::Base like 'order' and other relation methods.

Assuming we have

  class DeveloperOrderedBySalary < ActiveRecord::Base
    self.table_name = 'developers'
    default_scope :order => 'salary DESC'
    scope :by_name, :order => 'name DESC'
  end

Calling DeveloperOrderedBySalary.by_name will overwrite the default scope order (there is a test for this: test_named_scope_overwrites_default).

But if we use the relation syntax

  class DeveloperOrderedBySalary < ActiveRecord::Base
    self.table_name = 'developers'
    default_scope order('salary DESC')
    scope :by_name, order('name DESC')
  end

DeveloperOrderedBySalary.by_name will not overwrite the ordering, but will concatenate it. I guess this is expected behavior according to https://rails.lighthouseapp.com/projects/8994-ruby-on-rails/tickets...

But then I expect reorder to work in the named scope:

    scope :by_name, reorder('name DESC')

but this fails with undefined method reorder'</code> exception. This is because reorder is not delegated in ActiveRecord::Base like 'order' and other relation methods.
version.title: Impossible to overwrite the default scope ordering in the named scope

version.body:
Thus I have added <code>reorder<code> to ActiveRecord::Base delegations. Also I have added the test.
Please review the patch and comment if I have done something the wrong way. I don't know exactly where to add the test, so I modified the existing model DeveloperOrderedBySalary. Maybe I should have created new model to test named scopes ordering specifically.
version.body-html:
Thus I have added reorder to ActiveRecord::Base delegations. Also I have added the test.

Please review the patch and comment if I have done something the wrong way. I don't know exactly where to add the test, so I modified the existing model DeveloperOrderedBySalary. Maybe I should have created new model to test named scopes ordering specifically.

(from [b75fca9e57423eec81384ff3e35f38fd4f7fe47f]) Added reorder delegation for ActiveRecord::Base(to be able to overwrite the default_scope ordering in the named scope [#5093 state:resolved]
Signed-off-by: José Valim <jose.valim@gmail.com> http://github.com/rails/rails/commit/b75fca9e57423eec81384ff3e35f38fd4f7fe47f

version.body: This supra footwear is called a modern vintage and has been since their introduction in 2003 where they began in Europe. Every supra shoes has some type of ornament, adornment or hardware and is comprised of aged leather that is bought from around the world. These supra uk are culturally engaging and allow for the woman wearing them to be enveloped in luxury.With new cuts and styles and hand stitched shoes, these timberland boots, heels or flats will make every foot look like it stepped out of vintage Hollywood. This timberland shoes have been worn and coveted by many of the most famous females in recent history. One such coach outlet, Jennifer Aniston, wears them in public and at home.This company makes many different unique styles of bags outlet from ankle booties to sandals, pumps, moncler jackets online, platforms and wedges. One louis vuitton bag in particular is ideal for the gothic style sense; it is patent leather and laces up the front of the shaft. There are also zippers on each side, and this shoe offers a flat heel of a half inch.Another great moncler jackets sale is featured in People's Style Watch and is called a platform bootie. This ture religion jeans has a raised panel in front of the ankle as well as a heel that measures 4.5 inches. The front offers a leather bandage appearance and is considered high fashion.
